Then once the last man was patted against the wall they left us waiting in a hot humid tunnel for about 20 min. Once in the ferry they lined us up to get our food tray and say this or that. I said hmm what\'s that, they said it\'s this or that keep the line moving. And just like you see in all those movies where the cafeteria people slap the blop of food on your plate, is what they were doing to everyone. 6 hrs later we arrived... I will play Devils advocate and say the treatment was due to the fact they were delayed but this was my experience.

586214510.name: took ferry to Pichilingue
586214510.author: a TripAdvisor user
586214510.reviewBody: Actual ferry trip was smooth sailing. \ninformation flows within ferry operator are deficient. We had wanted-we and several others-to take ferry to Mazatlan as per their website. Ferry was cancelled until further notice but not so indicated on website.

575927645.name: Baja Ferry tickets, Los Mochis, & Uber
575927645.author: a TripAdvisor user
575927645.reviewBody:
Baja Ferries,  Los Mochis,  and Uber

We took ferries from La Paz to Topolobampo and back.  Our walk on experience :

Being as it was a day time trip,  we thought we would just enjoy being on the deck,  enjoying the sea,  perhaps spotting some sealife. We did do this,  but found the 7 hours to be overkill,  especially being as there are barely 3 metal benches upon which to sit.  The sun was hot and when there was no shade,  unbareable.  
We moved to the lounge area:  comfortable for awhile,  until a live band began playing.  While the music wasn't bad,  it was incredibly loud. 
We moved the the theater which was showing action movies in Spanish.  Not to begrudge Spanish speakers,  but not ideal again for us: loud w no subtitles. 
We moved to the dining room- nice, but after so many hours, we were not excited to sit in straight back chairs and listen to loud Spanish TV. 
We found there was no escaping the noise but for sunny outside- our best option for this trip. 
(There were available cabins to rent on board,  but it wasn't until 4 hours into the trip that we became desperate for some comfort and quiet- a hard time to spend the $50 or so to take a room.) 
Advice- Reserve a dang cabin to save your sanity.) 

Being as the ferry to La Paz leaves Topolobampo at midnight,  we reserved a cabin in advance,  hallelujah!  The cheapest cabin was small,  clean,  w full bathroom,  and glorious for sleep.  

With a good enough meal to tide us over the hours,  the ferry is a fine way to travel.  But take a cabin,  both ways. 

Other notes:  If you want to book a hotel for first nights on the mainland,  do so in Los Mochis- approximate 20 miles inland from Topo.  (Fiesta Inn,  while nothing culturally exciting, was clean with a variety of good restaurants next door.)   From Los Mochis,  use Uber for great prices back to Topo or to El Fuerte.

567026695.name: Comfortable Ship, Efficient vehicle boarding, Support Animal Ok, Recommended
567026695.author: a TripAdvisor user
567026695.reviewBody:
Ok, Admittedly, I speak Spanish, so things are easier for me in Mexico, but there's one review here calling the Ferry a 'HORRID bureaucratic process for US Residents' and I want to counter that. That driver, who has supposedly driven to Mexico many times, was clearly unprepared. People need passports to cross borders, and vehicles need temporary import permits. I've gotten them myself several times and they're very easy to obtain. Again, I speak Spanish, but if you don't, don't blame the Mexicans for not being able to communicate - that's your responsibility when traveling in their country. 

So, my experience from La Paz to Mazatlan was GREAT! I live most of the year in Puerto Vallarta and was driving my Mexican car, so I didn't have any of the 'temporary vehicle import' paperwork to do. If you're driving a US or Canadian vehicle, you will need such a permit. They're actually very easy to get and you can do it online before you leave your country. They will FedEx the permit to you and you're done. I've done it 3-4 times myself. 

This is a ferry, not a cruise ship, so tone your expectations down and you'll be fine. I had a Jr. Suite, only about $30 USD more than a regular cabin, and I got a balcony, though they have the sliding windows screwed shut which was a bummer. The dining room is cafeteria style and the food was adequate. They had live music for a few hours and the entertainers were really good at involving the younger crowd and everyone had a good time. The rear deck is open air and a nice place to watch when you sail out and when you arrive. There was a fooz ball table, a bar, a tiny 'cafe' and a bit of a gift shop. There are two large lounges, set up like a stripped down business class section of an airliner. There are 9 big leather, comfy-looking seats per row, separated by 2 aisles, again just like an airplane, with lots of flat screens and they show movies all night. I was surprised at how violent one was and all the kids sitting there, but I'm not a parent, so not my issue. If you are a parent, beware... If you don't take a cabin, this is the most comfortable place for you to spend the 13 hour trip. 

So, boarding was really easy, and so efficient. They obviously do this a lot and the skids are well-greased. As is typical in Mexico, there aren't many directional signs, so when driving from section to section of the docks, you may need to ask for help. Because of an event in La Paz, our ferry left a couple hours late, so I was doing this in the dark which I'm sure also made is harder. 

I drove out to the docks the day prior and bought my ticket at the office there. I wanted to get the lay of the land, so I knew what to expect. I'm glad I did. They give you several tickets which are collected at various points during the boarding process. I was traveling with my dog who is a registered service animal. They wanted copies of his certificate and letter from my doctor. And they asked to see his leash tag and red support vest. Not many businesses in Mexico recognize service animals, so this was a treat! Otherwise, your pet will be in a locked pet room with others and you MUST have a secure crate for him to travel in. You cannot enter the room, but you can peer through the window. My service dog stayed with me the entire time, but was restricted to the cabin and required to be in his crate. That was no problem for me. 

When I got to the dock, the first thing is Mexican Customs. This is a major shipping route, so lots of goods going back and forth, lots of big semi trucks, etc. My car was loaded with personal possessions for my home, so I had no duty to pay. Also a word of advice for gun-loving Americans and people traveling with any drugs, including 'medical' marijuana. All firearms and ALL drugs are totally illegal in Mexico. If you somehow got across the border without getting arrested, you are going through customs again here. If you have weed with you, dump it before you get to the docks and buy it again when you get to the mainland. It's not worth it.

So, after they inspected my vehicle, next is the weighing in and the measuring. At this point, you will also pay a customs tax which you don't pay when you buy your ticket. I think it was $176 pesos, so roughly $10 USD. Then, you drive to your ship. I drove up, they took another of my tickets, then directed me to drive into the belly, back into place and that was that. So simple. I must say I was really surprised at how simple it was. I've lived full and part time in Mexico for 14 years and rarely are things things simple. Again, I speak Spanish and I know that helps. If you don't, it will doubtlessly be more complicated, but it's your lack of understanding, not their lack of established process. I had previously packed a napsack with only what I needed for overnight, so I grabbed it and went up to Reception. At reception, I was assigned a steward to assist me - I suspect this is because I had a Jr. Suite. I noticed near me were also 3-4 VIP suites, but I didn't see anyone else being helped to their cabin. You will leave your ID at Reception and they'll return it to you when you return your key in the morning. 

The Sea of Cortez was very calm and there was only a very gentle rocking at times. I thoroughly enjoyed my trip, slept fairly well. The cabin was cold to me and I used blankets from another bed. Even in my Jr. Suite, there were 4 twin beds, 2 sets of bunks, Murphy style, that folded up against the walls. The bath had soap and shampoo provided and a hair dryer. I also had a little fridge with 2 complimentary beers, a couple bottles of water and I think a couple sodas. I used only the water. Oh, there is no WiFi and no cell coverage most of the way. 

Arriving in Mazatlan and the disembarking process could not have been easier. As soon as we arrived, the put down the ramps, announced for all drivers to line up at the door to go down to their vehicles. We walked down the stairs, into the belly, got into our cars and I was off the ship in 5 minutes. Once on the dock, the exit was clearly marked, leads right to a major artery and there was clear signage to the 15 Highway for my 6-7 hour drive to Puerto Vallarta. I was home by late afternoon.

All in all, this was a really comfortable way to travel. The total cost for me was about $250 USD, I think $4650 pesos. The cabin was only $1350 pesos, the rest was for my car. It was also a bit of an adventure and I would highly recommend people do this. If you're going to be in La Paz or Mazatlan and have the time, it would even be worth it to take the ferry for a couple day side trip to the other city. 

I would do this trip again in a heartbeat!

564029781.name: Comfortable overnight ferry
564029781.author: a TripAdvisor user
564029781.reviewBody: We took the ferry from La Paz to Mazatlan. Buy your ticket at the office in town. The staff did not speak English. We were driving so needed to pay for the car and 2 passengers in a cabin. They check your ID etc. At the port, which is outside of La Paz. The driver stays with the vehicle until boarded and passengers go into the terminal. Keep any luggage you need for the night with you. Food was mediocre, there is music until 11. Bed was OK. Next morning you arrive in Mazatlan and as a passenger just walk off. The drivers had to wait for the transport trucks to unload first

557384181.name: Great relaxing trip
557384181.author: a TripAdvisor user
557384181.reviewBody: Great way to get from Baja to Mazatlan. Very clean, like new facilities, dinner food was wonderful and had good variety, sleeping accordion very comfortable with full bath, quiet, relaxing, can watch movies all night sitting in spacious theater with with reeling first class seats.

555592815.name: Great Experience on Ferry La Paz-Mazatlan.
555592815.author: a TripAdvisor user
555592815.reviewBody: We recently took the overnight ferry on Baja Ferries from La Paz to Mazatlan.  We transported our vehicle and had a cabin w/ bath for the thirteen hour journey.  The Cabin had space for four beds, two being bunk beds; we chose the standard size room.  There was plenty of hot water and the bed was comfortable.  Our passage included Dinner and coffee/roll in the morning.  There was very good entertainment in the evening.  We both speak Spanish, but feel boarding the Ferry with a vehicle could be confusing for those without any Spanish, primarily because there are few personnel who speak English at the Port.  Also, we encourage obtaining your car permit at the Border or in Ensenanda, as Banjercito at the Port closes at 3:00 pm.  Fortunately, we found out that important piece of information before going to the Port, as the Ferry only runs three times a week.  In addition, make sure you pick up your tourist visa at the Border or in Ensenada; all foreigners are required to have one in Baja California.

550856393.name: Loved it
550856393.author: a TripAdvisor user
550856393.reviewBody:
More than I expected! If you live close to either end if their route, I urge you to take this voyage.
It was $225. American money for a private cabin including the show and food.
What a bargain! Plan to drink some and stay for the show.
Fabulous! Thank you baja ferry!

549803885.name: Easy passage
549803885.author: a TripAdvisor user
549803885.reviewBody: Took the afternoon ferry to Los Mochis so I could catch El Chepe the following morning.  Took the public bus to Tecolate beach for a few beers then back to Pichilinque to catch the ferry.  Nice waiting area if you want to eat or pick up snacks.  I rented a room since I had been to beach but it wasn\'t necessary.  There is plenty of deck space to watch the scenery as you depart and the sunset after.  Passengers were mostly truck drivers and a few local tourists, dinner was included in the price and was very good.  About half the trip is daylight and there are plenty of taxis to take you to Los Mochis once you dock.

547548625.name: Mazatlan to La Paz
547548625.author: a TripAdvisor user
547548625.reviewBody: I was very satisfied with the trip. Told to get there 3 hours early to load my car. Bought the cheapest cabin, which was fine. Very clean, spacious and comfortable for one person, and my own bathroom with shower. I was told that an Italian company built the ferries, and it shows in it being well designed. Cost a little over $200 total. Dinner was nothing to write home about and I didn\'t go up for breakfast. Felt like it took a long time to get out of there when we got to La Paz. A lot of waiting. Turned in my room key before 7:00, got into my car around 8:15, then stopped 3 times on the way out--had to pay under 100 pesos for something upon leaving (don\'t speak much Spanish, so I often have no clue what is going on) had to stop for military to inspect my car (asked if I had any fruit with me) and had to stop and pay 30 pesos for some guy to spray my tires with what I can only guess was weed killer. The only regret is that there was no travel during daylight hours, so you don\'t get to see dolphins, whales, fish or whatever else might be seen along the way if it were not at night. It was nice and quiet for sleeping, but I seem to feel exhausted anyway. Maybe because I\'m not used to getting up so early. Anyway it sure beats driving and I recommend it. I tried to buy online, but couldn\'t get the English version to work at all, and when I used the Spanish version, I thought it went through, but it didn\'t accept my payment for some reason, even though it gave me a confirmation number, so I went to the office and bought it in person, 5 days prior, which is probably the way to go anyway.

546706262.name: VIP room
546706262.author: a TripAdvisor user
546706262.reviewBody: We purchased the vip room. What a great deal. The room was large and comfortable.  \nDinner was included but it was that good, just so so.

544687687.name: A pleasant surprise
544687687.author: a TripAdvisor user
544687687.reviewBody: We travelled from La Paz to Maxatlan. We got the cheapest cabin and were pleasant surprised - the beds were comfy, the whole room was beautifully clean and had plenty of plug sockets, plus a large fan. We had our own bathroom with a decent shower; towels, soap and shampoo were also provided. The on-board meal was pretty tasty and plentiful. You get a small breakfast roll and coffee too. The staff were efficient and friendly; we set off on time and arrived early. All in all, a really positive experience. And a much better night\'s sleep than on a 13hr flight!

542542103.name: A \u201cmust do\u201d experience if ever in the Baja Cali or Sinaloa areas of Mexico.
542542103.author: a TripAdvisor user
542542103.reviewBody: We split are vacation locations into two just so we could try the ferry experience.  We started in Cabo San Jose.  Bought our two, private cabin tickets in downtown Cabo San Lucas.  Took a regional (Greyhound type bus line) bus trip three hours along the Pacific coast and across the peninsula to LaPaz. The ferry is one of the major logistics route between Baja California and mainland Mexico.  The ferry is loaded with every type of truck imaginable, including cars, motorcycles and power boats on trailers.  Takes several hours to load the trucks and vehicles.  The passengers begin boarding about 90 minuets before departure after going thru several security checks.  We checked into our four person private cabin, with bathroom, shower, sink, tv and a large window facing the sea.  A light dinner is served by the crew a few minutes after boarding.  Once underway, the trip takes about 12 hours. Unloads unceremoniously in La Paz and took a taxi to our next destination.

542016269.name: A surprisingly good travel
542016269.author: a TripAdvisor user
542016269.reviewBody: We took the night ferry from Topolobampo to La Paz. As we arrived quite early to book tickets and a cabin, we had to wait a long time in the office/canteen. I definitely wouldn\'t recommend that there is nothing to do but some fast food places and the space is uninspiring at best. However, the people helping us with our tickets were really nice and when on board we got a very nice cabin for 4 people, just occupied by us. Nice beds, a good bathroom with hot water. Actually everything you need for a relaxing night. We skipped the food, entertainment and shops, but slept well and arrived early but fresh in La Paz.

541610159.name: We had a lovely time -- easy booking and a fun, comfy trip
541610159.author: a TripAdvisor user
541610159.reviewBody:
I realize that people can have bad experiences when traveling, even at good places.  But I have to admit I don’t understand why this ship and this company get such awful reviews here.  My partner and I were very satisfied and we had a great time.  From booking the tickets on the phone in English, to fixing an error in the spelling of my partner’s name at the Mazatlán ticket office, to the trip itself, I really couldn’t find anything to complain about.

I’ll write a long review because I think it’s worth adding a positive point of view to all the negatives that have been expressed.

Short version:  it’s great.  You have nothing to fear – except maybe being peer-pressured into singing karaoke in Spanish in the bar.
 
Longer version:

If you expect a luxury cruise, you’ll be disappointed.  But if you want a clean, safe, comfortable, fun and cheap way to cross between Mazatlán and La Paz, I highly recommend the ferry.  As it happens, our fare for two passengers in the most expensive private cabin on board cost almost exactly what two airline tickets would have cost on the daily Calafía nonstop flight.  Smaller cabins or a seat in economy class are even cheaper.
 
We knew from reading the website that they require large suitcases to be checked – not because our room was too small (it was huge), but because some of the hallways on board are very narrow.  So we packed a change of clothes and our toiletries in an overnight bag.  Checking the suitcase was quick and easy, and it was waiting for us when we disembarked at La Paz.
 
We were told to arrive three hours before scheduled departure, which we did, and we boarded only about 15 minutes later.  Boarding was easy and well organized, and there’s an elevator for those who can’t handle the four or five flights of stairs from water level to the passenger quarters.  Once on the boat there was a virtually no wait to check in at reception, where we were given our key (in exchange for my ID, returned upon checkout).  A nice lady showed us to our room and described its features.
 
We left Mazatlán right on time at 6:30 pm, and arrived in La Paz on schedule just shy of 13 hours later.
 
We were in cabin VIP 4.  VIP 1 is the only other one as large.  They have a large sitting area with a sofa and coffee table, two queen beds, closet, desk, enclosed balcony with table and chairs, wall-mounted TV, a floor fan to supplement the AC, and a full bathroom with shower.  These are corner suites with side view and bow view.  The other two VIP cabins only face forward and are a bit smaller, probably with no balcony, but I’m sure they’re very nice.
 
Most of the other cabins appear to have bunk beds, but I got a peek into a few of them and they seem just fine.  Not as extensively furnished, but it’s a short trip.  If you just want a bed and a bathroom but plan to spend your waking time in the common areas of the ship, the standard cabins seem just fine.  As for the economy seats, well, they wouldn't be my first choice, especially considering the standard cabins are pretty cheap.  But the economy areas were clean and in good condition.
 
You can plug a HDMI cable into the wall-mounted TV, or borrow a DVD at no cost from the collection at reception.
 
The dinner isn’t the best meal you’ll ever have, but it wasn’t bad either. Basic airplane-quality food, served cafeteria style.  The restaurant is large and very clean.  Breakfast is a sweet roll and coffee or tea, shortly before arrival.
 
The bar/lounge is attached to the restaurant, offering bar service and table service.  They were still open and serving drinks when I went to bed around midnight.  There was a (really cheesy but fun) band that played from about 8:00 until 10:00, and then the karaoke guy took over.  It was a total blast to hang out with the tipsy truck drivers and sing romantic pop ballads in Spanish.
 
On the lower level is a small café and convenience store, offering coffee, hard and soft drinks, snacks, souvenirs and convenience items such as toiletries.  They closed around 11:00 and re-opened at 6:30.
 
I slept like a baby, and the next morning there was plenty of hot water for a comfortable shower.
 
Upon check-out, I returned my key, then waited about 5-10 minutes for my room to be inspected.  They called my name over the loudspeaker when the inspection was complete, and returned my ID.
 
It took a while to get off the boat.  For some reason, Baja California Sur imposes a security inspection upon arrival, and that really slowed things down.  From being told we could disembark to actually being in a taxi was probably 45 minutes.
 
Every crew member we interacted with was nice and helpful.  There was none of that apathetic, bureaucratic attitude you sometimes see in service people.  They all seem to like their jobs.  We interacted with them in Spanish, so I really don’t know how extensively English is spoken, although the guy at reception offered to help us in English if we needed it.
 
The downside:  it’s not a smooth voyage.  From the moment we hit open water the boat rocked from side to side, sometimes softly and sometimes more aggressively, but it was constant.  It didn’t bother me at all, but sometimes it put my partner off balance. Maybe not recommended for people prone to motion sickness.

All in all, we’re very satisfied and would travel again with Baja Ferries.

538781447.name: Soursweet experience
538781447.author: a TripAdvisor user
538781447.reviewBody: I took the ferry from La Paz to Mazatlan great welcome by Alfredo who reanimes ar out service and was great part of the crew. I got bug bites in my cabin dont know what was it but i was algo glad to find out how great is the pet area to consider for next time. Not so good the timings when we got to Mazatlan we remained on board like 1 hour and 15 min more and had to wait for an extra hour for the car to come out.

532681532.name: The customer service was so bad it never got booked
532681532.author: a TripAdvisor user
532681532.reviewBody: They would not confirm the booking and then raised the price and then cancelled. I have no confidence in them and will not trust my car or myself!

527460190.name: In My Experience Better Than 2 years Ago, But What Do I Know LOL
527460190.author: a TripAdvisor user
527460190.reviewBody:
you pay 25% for a single person/cabin with motorcycle of what a full size trailer pays
stuffed with a couple of hundred thousand bucks worth of merchandise
and when it comes to the on board meal the trailero gets a piece of cake
and the the rest of us a cup of inedible flan.

the 1st class cabins of Baja Star were in good shape, the common areas looked renovated
the prices are still steep and the boarding process chaotic and not pleasant.

They still have not heard of WIFI and half of the onboard reception crew is poorly trained.

their online booking sometimes accepts my credit card sometimes it does not
and their 800 number to a supposed call center only works when Pepe is awake.

Half of their ticketing staff in Mazatlan is poorly trained and has to struggle with
a cumbersome ticketing process that takes longer than buying an intercontinental 
airplane ticket.

Welcome to Baja Ferries, it's high time for some competition!

514034695.name: Disorganised
514034695.author: a TripAdvisor user
514034695.reviewBody: What a shabby experience.   No one knew what they were doing.  There were loads of "staff" all "doing their job".\nWe were given different instructions from one minute to the next.  We were not allowed to ride the bike together on the boat with the bike, then we couldnt get out luggage - chaos.   We we seperated as we loaded and then questioned as to why one was riding and one was passenger when ticket said motorbike.\nBoth loading and unloading were equally stressful.  The again chaos as we went through checkpoints, told ride the bike no walk with the bike, only one person no two people -  in the end we just laughed.   Took 2 hours from docking to get on the road.

508262709.name: Probably the worst booking and customer service out there
508262709.author: a TripAdvisor user
508262709.reviewBody: If you ever need to travel with this "company", make sure you book in person in some office, if you book online and there and issue you\'ll have a customer support hell coming, just to find that they are useless so they can\'t solve anything, plus you\'ll have to pay unjustified fees to fix the issues on the booking caused by their own system.\n\nI probably won\'t travel with them again.

486903630.name: Wonderful time across the Sea of Cortez..!!
486903630.author: a TripAdvisor user
486903630.reviewBody: Upon arriving in Mazatlan, I had my vehicle inspected and was surprised how easy the procedure was. The ferry left about 6.30pm without failure. I had a cabin reserved for the overnight cruise, and the staff was very friendly and courteous. The cabin itself was very clean and fresh.After putting my stuff away, I went up to the top deck to watch as the ferry departed. Wonderful views of Mazatlan and the coastline as it was a beautiful day. The tickets included dinner in the spacious restaurant, with music and a bar open for your pleasure. When I awoke in the morning, I was surprised with a beautiful view of the Sea of Cortez and the islands that lined the entrance to La Paz harbor. It was an easy trip, and the return was just as nice. I highly recommend this trip to anyone, with or without a car...!!

477312596.name: Beyond Bad...
477312596.author: a TripAdvisor user
477312596.reviewBody: The trip between topolobambo and la paz was more than 30 h delayed. That was not the worst part though. They squeezed in the passengers from the delayed (fully booked) ferry together with next days (fully booked) ferry. There was no info and as you can imagen there were 2 people per seat and per cabine... people were behaving like it was a warzone. The staff tried to hide. We were hearded like cows. We stood in a massive queue from 10 pm to 3 am. Oh did I mention the queue changed location three times (without info) and that people were running and whistling and screeming. When we verry tiredly reached our seats they were occupied and no one would help us. People were sleeping on the hard floor. Everywhere. Even outside.

475655758.name: A fun adventure
475655758.author: a TripAdvisor user
475655758.reviewBody: First, know that I\'m not a "roughing it" kind of girl, so I was worried about taking the Ferry from La Paz to Mazatlan.  We paid extra for a room, thank goodness, but many people just bring blankets and sleep on the floor or in chairs.  The trip was 11-12 hours long, but we slept peacefully on bunk beds in our cabin.  We also had a t.v. With a DVR to play movies that were free.  There was a large restaurant where we had a very tasty meal (included in our ticket price).  There was a movie theatre where many people passed the night in comfortable chairs.  We thought it was a unique experience.

471768673.name: Baja Ferry, La Paz to Mazatlan and back, with vehicle and dog
471768673.author: a TripAdvisor user
471768673.reviewBody: I am going to try and be detailed for those of you wanted all the info. My husband and I rode our motorcycle down to La Paz from the states and took Baja Ferry (specifically Baja Star) across the Sea of Cortez to Mazatlan back in late January. It was a 12 hour ferry, departing at 8pm and arriving at 7:30-8am the next day. Ferry\'s have different schedules so be sure to look it up online. They do not run everyday. (For those of you reading for animal info. we didn\'t have our puppy until traveling back to La Paz from Mazatlan in late March, so scroll down for that info.) Our experience leaving from La Paz wasn\'t bad, just very different then when leaving from Mazatlan. In La Paz, we were asked to get to the docks 3 hours before our ferry was scheduled to leave. The paperwork for the bike was a hassle, so I was glad we bought our tickets a few days before and not day of. Anyways, we arrived at 5pm to the docks (located about 20-30 minutes out of La Paz), our ferry scheduled to leave at 8. We pulled into the loading area and had to push a button to see if we would have to get our vehicle searched. It is totally random but our light happened to turn red, so we pulled open our bags and showed the employees. I have to say that they were very kind and even made small talk with us. No big deal there. After that, my husband and I had to separate because only one driver was allowed to go with the vehicle, regardless of if it was a car or moto. My husband had to pay about $4.00 USD to have the moto weighed which was silly because they make it mandatory, but it was quick and easy since we got there early. He waited in line with the other vehicles for quite a while even though we were some of the first passengers there, not being able to load until after most of the trucks since he had a small vehicle. I had to wait inside, an area similar to airport seating when waiting for a plane, until 7pm, an hour before the ferry was scheduled to leave. There were a lot of people traveling on the ferry which seems to be the norm. If you have a cabin, they let you bring your luggage with you, but if you just have a seat they make you check your stuff. At 6, they had everyone line up and go through a similar process as the car. They individually asked if I had any drugs or alcohol, I said no, then I had to push another button to see if my things would be searched. It turned green this time so I was free to head on without having to open my stuff. From there, I walked directly onto the ferry. You walk through the truck/car loading area on a designated pathway, lead by an employee. They take you to a door that leads up some steep stairs to the boat\'s reception area. My husband said they allow the drivers to take an elevator, so that is an option. Though I wouldn\'t say the ferry (Baja Star) was brand new, it is very clean and well maintained. They have AC running so it is cool, even though the cities are hot. I checked in at reception, but they wouldn\'t give me the key to our cabin because my husband had the cabin ticket. So i waited about 45 minutes for him to make it to the reception area. He had to give up his ID to get the room key, but was given it back the next morning no problem. The cabin was very simple, but nice. We got one with a window and TV, though the Tv had no channels. The window is definitely nice if you tend to get sea sick, though not necessary at all. The room had 4 twin beds in it, sort of like bunk beds, and a clean bathroom with towels, toiletries, shower, sink and toilet. It also had lots of storage, including a cabinet with life vests. It was comfortable and very clean for a night\'s stay. We had 0 issues with the room. If you don\'t purchase a cabin ($45 and up) you are assigned a seat, similar to a nice airplane seat, in a certain room. The downside to this is that they have TV\'s blasting movies all night long, and the rooms are cold. If you choose this option, i suggest earplugs and a blanket.. I read a lot of reviews about people complaining about the included dinner, but it wasn\'t bad at all. You get to choose a main, like chicken or beef, then they also give you refried beans, rice, corn tortillas, a choice of water or soda, and jello. If you are super high maintenance, it won\'t be good enough for you, but we were thankful for the food. They have vending machines on site with snacks and drinks, and they also have a bar, as well as other food options in the restaurant area.  In the restaurant itself, they had a live performer singing, meaning people were getting up and dancing and having a good time. Dinner is usually served between a 2-3 hour window, so you have plenty of time to settle in, then go eat. The ship also has some entertainment things like fooseball table, air hockey, video games, and stuffed animal machines. They have live announcement going off every once in a while in both Spanish and English. The only time this is annoying is at 6AM. They also have a small shop on the boat, tax free, with perfumes and some alcohol. Breakfast the next morning is not included, though they serve coffee and pastries for cheap. Once we arrived in Mazatlan, they made several announcements and had security guards all over on the boat to help you figure out where to go. Once again, my husband and I had to separate, he getting in line to go down with the drivers, and me exiting by foot. Exiting into Mazatlan is a little confusing because the cars don\'t exit in the same place, so make sure you have communication with whomever you are with if you have a vehicle so you can find each other. We left right on time at 8PM, and arrived right on time between 7:30 and 8 am the next morning. No issues. Overall, I would give this trip a 5/5. \n\nNow for Mazatlan back to La Paz. Purchasing the ticket this time was super easy. The dog was free, and we got a cheaper cabin this time, one with no window. Simple, 4 twin beds and a bathroom. It was nice, I would get that one again to save the few bucks that the window and the tv cost. It was clean and well stocked. Anyways, we bought our tickets 3 days before the ferry was scheduled to leave. This time the ferry was to leave at 6:30, though the office employee didn\'t tell us we needed to arrive 3 hours early like in La Paz. The lady at the office told us we HAVE to bring our own dog cage. She said it had to be a hard cage, but no one ever checks. We said ok. If you are scrambling to find one, both Walmarts in Mazatlan sell them for between $20.00-$50.00 depending on the size you need. There are also local pet stores that sell pet carriers, though it won\'t be comfortable for your pet. We used a carrier and we wished we didn\'t because she was stuck laying down the entire time. We arrived to the dock about 2 hours early this time, and separated again, my husband going with the moto and me by foot with our puppy. I only had to show my passport and ticket to a random lady standing in a heard of other passengers, and then wait about 20 minutes until they start letting us board. No one even checked to make sure I had a pet cage or anything. The only security procedure was a military man with a dog making us set our luggage on the ground and having the dog sniff it. That was it literally. It took 30 seconds and then we got on the actual boat, this time much earlier than just an hour before, once again lead by an employee to a door and up some steep stairs. By the time I got on the boat, about 4:45-5:00pm, my husband was already on. He didn\'t have to wait behind all the other cars to load the moto, and like me, security was very simple getting onto the boat. I took my ticket to reception and the lady was going to have a man escort us to our room. If you have a pet, you could easily sneak them into your room by having one person hold them in their carrier nearby while the other is shown the room by the employee, then meet up later. The lady didn\'t even look at my information other then my cabin ticket. This being our first time, we didn\'t do that. The man showed my husband to the "Area de Mascotas," a very small room on the upper deck, not cold or hot, but just small, locked with a pad lock at all times. We had to set our puppy on the floor or on one of the shelves in her pet carrier and leave her there. (We read other reviews saying some ferry\'s have built in cages, and some have rooms for pets and some don\'t) I guess all ferry\'s are different. This one had no pre-built-in cages. Anyways, the employees had no problem letting us go visit her when we wanted to, however, you have to ask reception and someone has to accompany you because they have to unlock the door, wait for you, then lock it again. It was a hassle and felt rushed because they had to wait on you, it wasn\'t like we could sit and play with her for an hour. We were not allowed to walk her or let her leave the little room. She was in there for a total of 13.5 hours. There is nowhere for her to poop or pee, so she ended up peeing A LOT in her pet carrier. It was pretty sad and I was surprised they wouldn\'t let us take her to the bathroom. The ship didn\'t end up leaving until 8PM, and we didnt get in on time either. We got our included dinner, same as the other ferry ride, and once again it was good. We headed to our room and hung out for the evening after walking around the ship a bit. You are allowed to be on the deck which is nice if you need fresh air. The next morning, we woke up at 6:30, expecting to arrive in La Paz by 7:30, but we didn\'t have to even get out of bed until 8AM. The ship didn\'t dock until about 9am, and we didn\'t get off until about 9:30 or later. They wouldn\'t let us get the dog until vehicles were able to unload, so even though we went to see the puppy around 8 to feed her and give her water, we had to put her back in the cage for another 1.5 hours until it was time to get off with out vehicle. If you are taking your pet, I suggest a nice carrier with room for them to stand up, a hook-on water dish, and maybe a pee mat. Even though it is super sad doing it, if you must take the ferry with your animal, it is totally doable. When I finally got my puppy, I had to exit the boat, and there was nowhere for me to take her to the bathroom because I had to go through security-a metal detector, and have someone check my documents. Of course, because I was a white girl by myself, I was the only one stopped and asked to show my passport and get asked questions in the middle of the building, well my dog wasn\'t in her cage because I had to walk her through the detector out of the cage, so she popped a squat and peed and pooped right on the floor. Then I got yelled at which was ironic because I was forced to take her our of her carrier by security in the first place. But (sorry to say) I didn\'t care. I cleaned it up of course, but what else was she supposed to do? Especially because she\'s a puppy and wasn\'t allowed to go to the bathroom on the boat for over 12 hours. Anyways, I met my husband outside and we were off. Finding him this time was much easier. I would rate this ferry a 3/5 only because of the animal situation and late departure/arrival time, everything else (dinner, boat quality, cabin, etc...)  was nice. If you have specific questions, ask the employees in the BajaFerry office in person when buying your tickets. Don\'t just assume stuff. Especially because the website is not very specific.

470947807.name: From Topolobampo-La Paz and back to Topolobampo
470947807.author: a TripAdvisor user
470947807.reviewBody:
WOW! I asked a friend who lives in the area what to expect. He said that it'd been years since he'd traveled the crossing there, but that he remembered it as spartan and not to expect too much. He missed it by miles. The experience was wonderful. 

TOPO-LA PAZ
I had a cabin on the way over to La Paz (as it was an overnight run) and I was impressed.  The cabin was clean and comfortable. The bath was spotless and had a nice shower and the water was hot. The bed was perfect. The A/C blew cold (maybe a bit too cold for some, but I think you can get extra blankets at reception).

A cafeteria-style meal is provided and I had a seafood medley stew (shrimp, crab, octopus, clam) with rice. You an get drinks in the restaurant or in the bar for reasonable prices.

One American passenger was complaining because they didn't speak enough English. It's Mexico, folks; deal with it. You can find someone (a ferry-worker or a passenger who speaks a bit of English) if you get in a bind.

I took a bus from Los Mochis to Topolobampo then got a taxi to the ferry terminal from the bus stop in Topo.

LA PAZ - TOPO
I travel back tomorrow on the afternoon run and will update this with more info on that run. I didn't get a cabin as it's not an overnight trip.

GENERAL
Get to the terminal early to make sure you have time to board. If you feel lost, ask questions. They run passengers through a quick security scan (x-ray, metal detector) before boarding, but didn't take away any thing like pocket knives and such. 

If you get a cabin, locking the door when you go out was a little tricky. Just try a few different combinations with the knob. I got it to work.

470441171.name: Gets you from A to B, that\'s all
470441171.author: a TripAdvisor user
470441171.reviewBody: Fairly basic seating. Bad food. Long wait to get tickets, long wait to get off once docked, then again for baggage. Needs to be streamlined.

468397849.name: cargo ferry
468397849.author: a TripAdvisor user
468397849.reviewBody: The cargo ferry sails every other day when the passenger ferry is not available.  We were warned the service was subpar.  We spent the night in a chase-lounge in a common area. The snorers were sometimes annoying.  The food could be characterized as grub and certainly needs improvement.  We wanted to arrive to Mazatlan as soon as possible so under the circumstances I can\'t complain much.  Mexican security is almost always polite (unlike the US and Canada), though sometimes unnecessarily lengthy.

464374177.name: Dirty, Disorganized, freezing cold room with broken thermostat, shower wouldn\'t drain
464374177.author: a TripAdvisor user
464374177.reviewBody: Dirty, Disorganized, freezing cold room with broken thermostat, shower wouldn\'t drain.  I can\'t say enough bad about the experience with 2 exceptions:   Great Tequila selection & good dinner.  They only make some announcements in English AND when checking in they don\'t tell you won\'t time you\'ll need to depart, consequently they suddenly announce you have to leave your cabin (we were right in the middle of showering).  Upon departure they sent all the drivers down to the car floor at once, which had no ventilation, everyone had their cars running & they could only take two cars up at once, with no ventilation.  I will NEVER use them again.

463617722.name: All in all, it was a good experience. Glad we did it.
463617722.author: a TripAdvisor user
463617722.reviewBody:
After many years of wanting to take the ferry, my wife and I finally boarded at Mazatlán, in mid-February 2017, to sail to La Paz. I think there are at least 2 ferries available. We embarked as passengers; no car; and, all in all, it was a good experience. 
Here are the pertinent items: 
* I purchased our cabina tickets online without a hitch (I couldn’t believe it was so easy and the website worked pretty well except for a big glitch mentioned below) and, although the web page announced a 5:30 p.m. departure (begin loading at 2:30), the Mazatlán office said 6:30 and, by gosh, the ship got going at 6:30 on the button. Arrival time was 7 a.m. the next morning and we were there on time too. 
* The boarding was a bit confusing because we didn’t know how the baggage reception procedure went, and no one told us, so we had to look carefully and ask questions (we speak Spanish, few English speakers around). We discovered we had to line up our bags at a certain spot for them to be loaded separately. And, at the last minute, we also learned that you are allowed to take only 1 bag per person per cabina for use during overnight, so we scrambled unceremoniously on that account as the bags were being loaded. In other words, if you want your tooth paste or your nightgown overnight, make sure you pack it in the one bag allowable because your other baggage is stowed separately. 
* Climbing aboard the big ship (with our bags, 1 each, the elevator came in very handy), we found very attentive ferry employees who answered our questions and directed us to our cabin which we found to be clean though Spartan. We found the bathroom small but gleamy clean, supplied with tissue, toilet paper etc. Beds were thin-mattressed but adequate, bottled water, etc. The ferry décor in general was steel, glass, and chrome; antiseptic and clean as a whistle.
* Eating on the ferry was good for folks without strict diets like mine. The food, served cafeteria style, was mostly Mexican (picadillo, roasted chicken, beans, rice, tortillas) with jello dessert, plus non-alcoholic drinks, all included in the price of our ticket, alcohol was sold separately. The eating area was shared with the night-club zone so we ate our repast as we listened to a live woman singer with a hefty repertoire accompanied by recorded Mexican music. Except for a couple of raucous fans, we enjoyed the show. Guards were in attendance all the while. 
* Even though we had cabinas we were also assigned seats in a large auditorium equipped with TV screens. Like the ferry in general, the room was hospital-clean and about as inviting. Ferry riders without cabinas spent the night in this room; the chairs, not unlike economy airplane seats, looked comfortable. 
* A majority of the passengers on our ferry were young Mexican males who were dressed, more often than not, in jeans, light jackets and tennis shoes; more like American high school youngsters, but with a rural touch. Inquiring with the ferry officials they informed me these lads were on their way to work in agricultural jobs in Baja. They were low-key and respectful. 
* My wife and I were astonished at the amount of traffic the ferry transported from the mainland to Baja. It explains why ferry officials require a 3 hour loading time. Most of the vehicles were truck and trailer combinations. The quantity blew our mind. 
Problems:
--This is the big glitch. When I ordered our tickets online I inadvertently did so requesting 2 cabins when we needed only one. I discovered this error late and their website is not mistake friendly. When I appealed to the ticket agents in person in the Mazatlán office, the response was cool and limited. They could only give me a credit good for one year. So, when you get your tickets online, go slowly and deliberately! 
--The other problem as that the office girls in Mazatlán behaved more like Mexican government employees, not very responsive to the customer. I didn’t know that you had to take a number to be attended to, and complained because I didn’t see any signs telling you so. 
Otherwise, the Baja Ferry was a good experience!

462048853.name: A good way to see the other parts of Mexico
462048853.author: a TripAdvisor user
462048853.reviewBody: Generally the ferry was ok. We took a room for us with children to sleep on the way from Mazatlan to La Paz and back. The ferry itself is not new. But everything was surprisingly clean. In the night it was a bit cool because there were just thin blankets and you don\'t expect to get cold after the day temperatures. But take some warm pyjamas with you! And the diner you get on board is included in the ticket but do not expect something special. Rice with some spicy meat and that\'s it. So if you can take something with you.

451595096.name: Overall good trip
451595096.author: a TripAdvisor user
451595096.reviewBody: We took the ferry from Mazatlan to La Paz.  Two adults and our vehicle.  Boarding was very organized.  Be aware that only the driver may go with the vehicle; any additional people must board separately.  We had an interior cabin and it was nicer than we expected and we slept well.  Announcements were done in both Spanish and English.  My only complaint would be disembarking.  Again only the driver may be in the vehicle as it exits the ferry.  For some reason, announcements during disembarkation were only in Spanish.  Then the driver must go through security and completely exit the terminal without stopping.  The driver must drive around and re- enter the complex to pick up any passengers and they can only do this once all vehicles have exited.  Took over an hour for my husband to be able to come back and get me.  Would have been much better if there were a spot for drivers to pull in and pick up passengers before leaving the terminal.  Overall a good experience.

445456808.name: It got us to where we were going
445456808.author: a TripAdvisor user
445456808.reviewBody: Took the ferry from La Paz to Mazatlan.  We were in a Toyota Tundra and also had our dog.  Price wasn\'t too bad (around $265) for the truck and a private cabin for two.  Dog was free.  Gal  that took us to our cabin had an attitude because we didn\'t speak Spanish very well. Didn\'t really bother us.  Plenty of room in the cabin with two twin beds, a small sitting area and a good shower.  If you\'re planning on just doing the lounge, then bring warm clothes and earplugs (it is very cold and the movie is very loud).  There are a few couches out side of the lounge area, but not many.  Dinner wasn\'t too great, but came with the ticket.  Entertainment was music videos from the 70\'s & early 80\'s (pretty good stuff) along with the partying truck drivers.  Bring something for breakfast and snacks.  It was completely inhumane for the dog.  He was allowed out of his kennel, but not out of the small room that housed the mascotas.  I talked one of the workers into letting me walk him a bit out of the authorities sight.  15 hours is too long to keep a pet in complete captivity.  Basically, we all survived and the ferry got us where we wanted to go.  Next time, I would take the cargo ferry.  Price is about the same, but you can stay with your vehicle and so can your pet. \n

442318522.name: Bound to be the lowlight of your trip
442318522.author: a TripAdvisor user
442318522.reviewBody:
I took the ferry from La Paz to Mazatlan, then back from Topolobampo (more about this later) to La Paz as part of a motorcycle trip down the Baja Peninsula and then over to the mainland down to Puerto Vallarta. I had always enjoyed ferry trips on my motorcycle both in the US and in Europe, and though this was a great plan to see Baja on my way to my destination.

I was wrong. 

First there was the reservation thing. They lost my reservation, so no cabin. That's Ok, I will take a seat. No seats, but you can sleep in the chairs in the cafeteria. Not much choice, as the next ferry was in two days, and it was full also.

The cafeteria is at most 10 X 10 meters, and there are a couple of hundred people that have bought meals that are going to get them. Dinner, which is included in the price, was a long wait to get served cafeteria style, only to find out that there was no place to sit. And while the menu seemed good, fish or meat, they ran out of both about half way thru the crowd. I got tortillas and re-fried beans (out of a can) for dinner. 

The boat is really crowded, as it is clear that they oversold tickets. Pretty much anyone who showed up got on, and unfortunately it was just before Holy Week, so there was a lot of national tourist. You could not stand at the railing to look over the side, because it was always packed. 

The cafeteria was showing what seem like a endless loop of Jan-Claude Van Damme movies, ALL  NIGHT LONG, so you can image how much sleep was going on there.

Oh, and did I mention how late they are. It was supposed to leave at 2 and finally left at 5, then it was supposed to arrive at 11, did not make it until 3. But they made you line up to get on starting at 12, so there went 26 hours of my life. 

On the way back, I showed up at Mazatlan for my return trip I had already paid for, only to be informed that the boat would not be carrying passengers. Trucks have a priority and they were oversubscribed, so car and motorcycle passengers would have to go up to Topolobampo, 5 hours north and take a ferry over to La Paz from there. 

I did get a cabin for the trip back, and it was a lot more civilized, although again the food ran out and I again had tortillas with beans (although they were black beans this time, so there was some variety). And also, again, the trip was delayed by 3 hours, so another 5 hours of waiting around to get on.

I suspect that my experience was unusually poor, mostly due to the unfortunate timing. But there is no getting around the fact that the ferry caters to truckers, and everybody else should be thankful they make it safely to the other side.

Not doing that again, ever.

438100423.name: Great trip from La Paz to Mazatlan and back
438100423.author: a TripAdvisor user
438100423.reviewBody: First time ever on a ferry with my car. Great service! You have to buy the master cabin package as it\'s the best deal you can have. Ticket includes some food like dinner and breakfast. Room was clean. I felt safe all the time.\nWill use Baja Ferries again.

427752395.name: No boats los mochis to la paz
427752395.author: a TripAdvisor user
427752395.reviewBody: We went to the baja ferries in good hope of getting a ticket to go to la paz from los mochis. On the website this should be a daiky route, except for sundays. In their office the route is also advertised. However, the lady behind the counter informed us that the only option was to go to mazatlan first, and then to la paz. Adding some 20hrs to get there to the 7hr ferry trip.\n\nWe decided to take a plane instead. Disappointing.

425704732.name: Food poisoning
425704732.author: a TripAdvisor user
425704732.reviewBody:
Do not eat on the ferry! 
Took a ferry from Mazatlan to La Paz and had a cabin booked on 30th September. We didn't have a car. 
 
Evening meal consumed on the ferry left us ill for the next 5 days. 

Ferry left on time. Also arrived on time, but then there was a problem with a ramp so spent couple of hours waiting to leave the ship.

417451972.name: El Ferry
417451972.author: a TripAdvisor user
417451972.reviewBody:
We cleared customs and drove our loaded VW to the weighing station, which cost us an additional 176 pesos. This fee was in addition to our car importation fee and bond, freight fee for the car and transport for ourselves (approximately 5,000 pesos, $1US=18.55; note the bond is refundable within a specified time frame, 90 days in our case). 

With our tickets in hand, we split up; only the driver may stay with the car, passengers must wait in the ferry building lobby. Within an hour, the guide car led about 70 vehicles at parade speed onto the muelle. Once past security, we carefully drove up the metal ramp and parked our vehicles onto two levels: semis, vans, passenger cars and trucks, even separate tractors and trailers.

My wife and I had rented una cabina, the key to which required the forfeiture of my driver’s license. She soon joined me, and we visited our cabin to drop off our overnight bags. The cabin was immaculate, the accomodations, while not on par with cruise ship standards, were adequate, and included a shower. The beds rivaled Army cots for their hardness, which I prefer.

Dinner was included in our fare, minus drinks and postres. The restaurant and bar were austere without being sterile. Menu options included chicken cutlets, macaroni, albondigas and frijoles, topped with a fiery salsa.

We retired early on an ESE heading, the distant laughter and odd echoes that reverberated deep within the ship soon blending with our snores. At six AM sharp, a woman’s voice disturbed the darkness of our slumbers and cabin, advising us that the restaurant was now serving coffee and simple breakfasts. We made it to the railing in time to capture the tail end of sunrise over the Sinaloa coast of western Mexico.

We packed up and out, returned the room key, and retrieved my license. The remainder of our time on board was spent watching the high rises of Mazatlán slowly resolve out of the morning fog.

Note that we sailed on the newest member of the ferry fleet. For roughly $300US, we crossed the aquamarine sea to engage with mainland Mexico. If you have the time, you should take the ferry, the direction is unimportant. Discovery begins within, and does not depend on your location. La Paz or Mazatlán are both rico y amable.

409544502.name: Interesting
409544502.author: a TripAdvisor user
409544502.reviewBody:
We took the ferry from La Paz to Topolobambo, and then back again.  On the way there it was pretty uneventful.  We rented a cabin so we could sleep and shower.  At one point, I went down to the main cabin, and it was full of people drinking and listening to loud music.  Made me glad we had a cabin.  

Our return trip was a nightmare.  While boarding the ferry, the split men into one line, with women and children in another.  As we slowly made our way to the ship, we passed through a small room where they allowed in 15 men, and across from us were 15 women.  There was a table between us.  They made everyone empty the contents of their pockets on the table.  Then a military officer passed a german shepard past everyone.  Another officer then passed by taking a picture of each and every person.  We were then asked to move onto the boat.  When we arrived, a military official stopped me and asked me for my passport.  I asked why.  He said for migratory information.  He looked at it, took out his cell phone, and took a picture of the page with all the data on it.  I was pissed of to no end.  I asked him how he would feel if he just spent a lot of money on a tour and he and his wife were treated like this.  He looked shocked that I asked.

I gave the review a 3 only because of the military harassment.  Otherwise, I would recommend the service.  If you do use the ferry, get a cabin.  It's not that expensive, and it is well worth it.

402953275.name: Delayed
402953275.author: a TripAdvisor user
402953275.reviewBody: We left with 1.5 hour delay and arrived with 3.15 have delay. The cabin though was nice, unfortunately they waked us when the arrival was scheduled in 30 min, but the ferry was delayed another 1.75 h which would have been nice to be able to sleep.

401113362.name: Bajaferries experience.
401113362.author: a TripAdvisor user
401113362.reviewBody: It\'s a good experience but they need more organization, you loose a lot of time waiting to board and to leave the ferry when you arrive.

387287809.name: Good facilities, BUT
387287809.author: a TripAdvisor user
387287809.reviewBody: The ship is in good maintenance, but the cooling system was not functioning correctly nor blowing cold air. The de-boarding process takes much too long; it took close to 90 mins to to vacate less than 100 passengers.

384405401.name: Very modern boat. Pity about the food and early wake up calls
384405401.author: a TripAdvisor user
384405401.reviewBody: A very pleasant surprise was how new the boat is. From La Paz to Mazatlan was to take until 9.00 am next morning. Getting on was no problem as not that many passengers. The drinks were cheap and good. Pity about the food. Dinner included in the ticket was as dry as could be. Basic cabin with 4 beds was excellent. Clean and comfortable. Why did the crew use the PA system to wake everyone up at 6.00 and again at 7.00 am?  They were promoting the breakfast which was a joke. Sweet biscuit coffee (which was not bad) and some warm chopped fruit. Finally the boat berthed at 10.00. Great vessel. Bad food and inconsiderate treatment of passengers\n

383184700.name: La Paz to the Mainland
383184700.author: a TripAdvisor user
383184700.reviewBody: Very clean - we booked a cabin with shower - slept so very well, dinner is included you just have to queue for your food, but only takes minutes.  It takes longer to go through th Customs and Immigration checks and that is not Baja Ferries\' fault!!

381298501.name: Good experience
381298501.author: a TripAdvisor user
381298501.reviewBody: We had a good experience with Baja Ferries. Food was ok, and sleeping in the TV-room was good as well. Don\'t expect luxury at the TV-room, but we had enough space to lie down. I don\'t know the quality of the rooms because they where all booked when we got our tickets.

369081503.name: An experience requiring patience and stamina
369081503.author: a TripAdvisor user
369081503.reviewBody:
We reserved passage for two people, our SUV and a cabin on the Baja Ferry from Mazatlán to La Paz because we wanted to drive home to Canada via the Baja. Booking on line was relatively easy and the cost, $380 Cndn, reasonable. We received an email a week in advance saying the sailing had been cancelled due to a ferry beak down and so we rebooked on the Topolobampo to Las Paz route. 
  
We were asked to arrive 3 hours in advance of the midnight sailing which we did but wondered why given we were the last to board three hours later. In the interim, we converted our paper reservation to tickets - one each for us, one for the vehicle and one for the cabin - and waited in the terminal. The loading, in Topolobampo, and unloading in La Paz, of trucks and commercial vehicles took over three hours each time. Passenger vehicles were loaded and unloaded last in each case. The ferry left 1 hour late for the 7 hour trip.  A meal was served after we boarded but we skipped it, presented our ticket to get a cabin key and went directly to it to get some sleep. There was no breakfast available in the morning -just coffee and packaged buns. Only the driver is allowed in the vehicle, for pre-and post boarding procedures. Other vehicle passengers must get on board and disembark with foot passengers. It took over an hour after we finally disembarked in La Paz to (1) have the driver's identity matched with the identity on the vehicle registration (and pay a 150 pesos fee), (2) go through a 2 stage army checkpoint and (3) have someone spray the vehicle wheels, supposedly for pests (20 peso fee). After this procedure, drivers went back to the terminal for their passengers. 

The down sides of the ferry trip were that our 7 hour midnight sailing took from 8:30 pm until 11:30 am the next day, the waiting was frustrating and the boarding/disembarking procedures seemed overly complicated. On the plus side, the ferry was clean and staff were friendly.  We would not call it a bad travel experience, just different. The value for us was it provided the opportunity to drive home via the Baja.

368092698.name: Need To Be Flexible
368092698.author: a TripAdvisor user
368092698.reviewBody:
We booked passage from La Paz to Mazatlán at the terminal about two weeks before we wanted to cross on our way by car to Ajijic.  We arrived at the terminal on the day of our voyage only to be told the ship was having maintenance all week so all trips to Mazatlán were cancelled.  Would have thought they would have known this when they sold us the ticket.  

There was ship going to Topolobampo so we got a refund for Mazatlán and booked to Topolobampo.  The ship left about 6 hrs late (suspect they waiting until after the sail time for the cancelled Mazatlán ferry). The voyage itself was uneventful.  One meal was served right after boarding and once the meal service ended a movie started.  There was also a large lounge where you could hang out. We booked a room.  Had four bunks and it own bathroom.  Was clean and reasonably comfortable. Because of the late departure, we arrived in Topolobampo at 2AM and then had to find a hotel room (you don't drive on Mexican highways at night, highways have to street lights and too many cows and horses wondering around).  Found a hotel right outside the terminal along with several others who were on the ship with us.

We left for Guadalajara at daybreak because landing in Topolobampo instead of Mazatlán added 5 hrs to our drive.  Finally made it to Ajijic around 8PM.

359592758.name: The shorter route to la Paz from the West
359592758.author: a TripAdvisor user
359592758.reviewBody: This was the most complicated and stressful ferry ride ever. Bureaucratic procedure and security concerns trump passenger comfort and convenience every time. However, the crossing itself, the comfort of cabanas and the other facilities were satisfactory. (A little real food for breakfast would have gone well with the morning coffee.) A few bilingual signs  helping the inexperienced traveller through a strangely complex process would have removed much unnecessary stress.

335926620.name: Good luck!
335926620.author: a TripAdvisor user
335926620.reviewBody:
At Mazatlán I was encouraged by a man who, having just arrived from La Paz, had enjoyed the trip.  I accept that lots of people make this trip without trouble but that wasn't my experience.  When I arrived at the terminal, the person at the window had the "no hay" (there isn't any) attitude which fortunately is rare in Mexico, saying there was a 5-hour delay without expressing any regret.  Paying M$1,102 (about £45) as a foot passenger, I expected a bit more.

The voyage itself was delayed further with a 3 hours hanging about outside La Paz waiting for a ferry there to leave.  There was no public explanation of this, let alone regret or apology.  Hence I missed a day of sightseeing in La Paz and was just thankful to have booked an overnight room there rather than continuing north that day.

To add hunger to injury, on the white board in the dining area they had initially announced two meals on the Saturday (breakfast and lunch) but despite the delay, this was mysteriously changed to one.  Hence I was ravenous on arriving at La Paz.

In La Paz the next day, I met a couple who had been on the ferry and were due to sail back to Mazatlán.  My reply was "!Buena suerte!"

334102642.name: very nice terminal
334102642.author: a TripAdvisor user
334102642.reviewBody: We were not on the ferry but went to see the newly built terminal, built in 2014. Great meals upstairs and very reasonable prices and oh so c!ean. The washrooms were also very clean. We watched the ferry arriving. Very impressive.

334084054.name: Better to fly
334084054.author: a TripAdvisor user
334084054.reviewBody:
We took Bajaferries from Topolobambo to La Paz. As per policy you have to be at the ferry 2 hrs prior to departure. So we had to get up before 4 am in order to take the boat which will leave at 6 am. However, it left only at 7.30 am with no information of the delay and we arrived with a delay of 1.15 in la Paz.

Infrastructure on the boat is quite poor. Toilets were dirty and food was mediocre.

Information on the delay was not available. I recommend to take plane from los Mojis to la Paz which is not much more expensive.

Bajaferries has signposts that the mission is to have good quality, but i consider it rather to be poor.

328018375.name: An experience!
328018375.author: a TripAdvisor user
328018375.reviewBody: We wanted the experience of traveling from Mazatlan to LaPaz by ferry as it seemed like a great way to see more of the area.  We were wrong!  You need to arrive 3 hours before departure time, which you end up sitting in their departure lounge, so not sure why they need so much pre departure time.  Even though we were to leave at 4, this ferry was still loading until 6ish and we finally were on our way after sunset.  So seeing anything in the dark was not happening.  You need lots of patience on this trip as we were aboard the ferry for about 22 hours.  The accommodations were what we were expecting, other than the room was freezing cold.  The meals were not great, but again we were e petting that.  We\'ve done it now, so we won\'t need to try it again.

318123704.name: lucky we made it to shore
318123704.author: a TripAdvisor user
318123704.reviewBody: decrepit people barge, a 90% discount would be adequate, don;t look at the life and death boats, or you\'ll get the creeps....

309953435.name: Long haul, disorganised
309953435.author: a TripAdvisor user
309953435.reviewBody: I was a little surprised at how the boat was, I was pretty modern for the Baja. That\'s about where it ended. Completely disorganised, only 1 port entry/exit on the boat with about 2000 people. It took about 1.5 hour to get on and off. Once on the boat it was a free for all for the seats and cafeteria area. If I need to take this the next time I will certainly get a room upgrade.

308588463.name: The domestic/International trip to Mexico
308588463.author: a TripAdvisor user
308588463.reviewBody:
I have been on the Baja Ferry twice this past summer and it is truly an international experience especially for a gringo member of the Mexico population.  This is not like any Ferry ride you have taken before.  You need a passport, export documentation for your vehicle if coming from La Paz, there are fees of all sorts "leaving" Mexico in LaPaz and then "leaving" Mexico in Los Mochis to come back plus an "export" deposit for your vehicle that you cannot get back unless you go to Tijuana to the "export bank" of Mexico to get your deposit back......Sound complicated??  You bet!

How about this? Once you drive your car on-board, you better have not forgotten anything because you won't be allowed back down to your car until you have arrived at your destination (Topolabampo or Mazatlan) and even then you will not be allowed on deck until all the trucks have been taken off.  This is not your Father's Ferry ride in Seattle or Staten Island.  You might as well be taking a ferry to Guatamala based on the way things are handled for a "domestic" ferry ride that never leaves Mexican territory in any way.

The good part of the ride is if you get a suite, especially from Topolabampo where you depart at 11pm and arrive at 7am or so.  The beds are very comfortable and they in-room bathroom is clean and terrific with a shower and the people on the boat working are very nice.  They just follow the rules and it is the rules that are stupid, not the people.  The food is good and the coffee is good!

It is an adventure and will give you plenty of cocktail stories when you get home!  Lastly, the best part of this ride is starting a drive that took us all the way to Cancun and back with over 3800 miles in mainland Mexico....it was the best drive ever and aside from some bureaucratic baloney like the Ferry ride, Mexico is a fabulous and lovely country with great people in every state and even better food everywhere.  Stop for the blue-corn cheese quesadillas in Tepic sold by the Huichal Indians in the city plaza....to die for!

294012923.name: Wonderful experience!!
294012923.author: a TripAdvisor user
294012923.reviewBody:
We booked our tickets online - to travel from Pichilingue, La Paz to Topolobampo, Los Mochis. Booking it on tehir website was easy and straight forward. Upon arriving at La Paz, we found out that there were some travel disruptions with our train travel from Los Mochis and had to change the date of our trip with Baja Ferries. We called them and were advised to go to their office to have the changes done and to collect the tickets.Our experience in this whole affair was a positive one. The staff at the office spoke English and had everything done for us without much problem and fuss.

We took a cabin for the trip and advised others to do so too, for the comfort of it. It was a nice, small cabin with 2 single beds and air-conditioned. Very comfortable. One serving of food was included in the price of the tickets and we had a sufficiently good meal at the dining areas with other passengers. The ferry was huge and we spent many hours when there was still light sitting on the upper deck on our collapsible camping chairs which we had brought along.

Our overall experience was a positive one. Upon our arrival at Topolobampo late at night, there were many taxis waiting for passengers at the port. So, our onward journey from there to Los Mochis was also smooth and very easy. Highly recommended!

292109788.name: Gives new meaning to the term "uncomfortable"
292109788.author: a TripAdvisor user
292109788.reviewBody: If you can\'t climb multiple flights of very narrow stairs, have trouble carrying your own baggage, or have the normal aches and pains of getting older, do not take this ferry ride. it is easier to drive the distance than to put thru this meat grinder. Appropriate for truck drivers and poor people used to living on the streets.

289554524.name: La Paz to Topolobamp very efficient, smooth and safe. It\'s a truck ferry, not a vacation cruise
289554524.author: a TripAdvisor user
289554524.reviewBody: Staff was very efficient and polite.  Voyage was smooth, on time and no complaints.  This is not a vacation cruise.  This is a transport ferry so don\'t expect lots of amenities, but the cabin was super clean, fairly comfortable bed and even had nice night lights, plenty of hot water, a great shower.  You leave La Paz at the Pichilingue dock about 20 min. north of the city (is a little confusing where you enter, looks like a truck entrance) and you go through lots of security to get on board. The departure was nice, a beautiful view of the Espiritu Santo Island, and a nice sunset, but the rest of the time I spent indoors.   Bring something to read or do unless you want to spend it outdoors, but be warned that you have no place to sit so have a hat, lean on the railing and enjoy watching flying fish.   There is a game room for kids, and the "bar/lounge" area looks like mostly truck drivers chilling in their comfortable chairs listening to super loud Norteno music on the TV monitors.   There is a another more family friendly dining area that has dubbed-in-Spanish US movies. On the trip back, it leaves late at night, so you eat, go to bed and wake up to the announcement of arrival.  Well maintained slightly older ship no frills but excellent crew.  If you need to go to Topo, take this ferry.

285058312.name: Gets you there, but have patience
285058312.author: a TripAdvisor user
285058312.reviewBody:
We took the ferry from La Paz to Mazatlan. We got from point A to point B, but it took some patience. We bought our tickets online - 2 adults in a sleeping cabin (very worth the money) and our car. We went to the office in La Paz to pick up our tickets. There was some confusion and we sat in the office for over an hour waiting. Unfortunately, we don't speak much Spanish and they didn't speak any English, but they were very nice and assured us we would be okay. 

We got our tickets and went to the port. This ferry, the one to Mazatlan, is really a cargo ship with some room for passengers. We were unclear of where to go or what the process was. We followed along, went through customs, then drove the car up on to the scales to be weighed, which cost a little bit (though this is not advertised anywhere, but we got a receipt and others were paying too), then we went through security. It was at this point, we didn't know what to do. So we waited. We found the other cars and sat with them. After an hour, the cars were called to load. I had to leave the car (only the driver can go on) and go into the terminal to load with the foot passengers. It all worked out, but patience is important. 

The ship was fine. We got two meals - dinner and breakfast (drinks are extra). The ferry took off about an hour late. We were to arrive at 11 am, but we didn't get in until almost 3pm. Bring some snacks. They sell them too, but it is all junk food. They play movies in the lounge and in the seating area. And you can go up on deck at any time, though they play the music pretty loudly, so it is hard to have a conversation. 

All in all, the trip was a fun adventure and worth it if you are trying to get to the mainland from Baja without having to drive all the way around.

272239014.name: Very nice crew and office staff
272239014.author: a TripAdvisor user
272239014.reviewBody: We moved from the mainland of Mexico to La Paz, BCS, Mexico.  We were greeted by Milagra at the office to buy our tickets.  She was so helpful and spoke English.  The ferry crew were so nice.  We had rented a cabin.  It has two sets of bunk beds and it was nice to have a shower and privacy.  Of course it\'s a bit warm and stuffy so we spent a lot of the time on deck chatting with other travelers.  It was I think about 15 hours give or take but I can\'t recall at this time.  The trip, including taking our two cats, was very nice.  They have an area for the animals and you cannot see them during the trip.  You have to wait until they come into port and be on the top deck ready to get them from the crew.

262589297.name: 5 hours waiting.
262589297.author: a TripAdvisor user
262589297.reviewBody: The "Lobby" is disgusting and we waited 5 hours before being allowed to board. Family of six with kids from 7 to 12... Once on board everything is much better, but so far a regrettable experience.

255709052.name: Extraordinary
255709052.author: a TripAdvisor user
255709052.reviewBody: Excellent, my my parents, one handicap with crutches and the other with a cane, were king and queen at the ferry. The staff ( included the personal where you get the permisdion for an out of coutry car and the ones selling the tickets) was amazing specialy with them, help and attention was always there. My sisters and myself were totally oriented about how to enjoy the almost 7hrs trip from La Paz to Topolobampo the best way possible. We had a small, clean and confy cab but my dad took advantage of the attention and moved all around the ferry. A pretty good, free meal is included with the ticket, there is a familiar bar and the restaurant is perfect. We want to take the trip again!

251917499.name: Perfect travel by sea in Mexico!
251917499.author: a TripAdvisor user
251917499.reviewBody: We traveled from Topolobambo to lampaz, 12 hrs journey during night, it was so good, we reserved a cab to sleep and have shower for journey, it was clean, and ok. Cabs are small but enoug to sleep with individual beds, if you want to sleep during the journey and be fresh the day after is good, but I bet Sunday journeys are worth as well, seeing the ocean

251613214.name: Good Experience with Private Cabin
251613214.author: a TripAdvisor user
251613214.reviewBody:
The line was very short if you get there early. I am very glad I opted for the private cabin, I slept several hours. 

The food was not too great if you are a vegetarian. There was a bar that was fine.

One tip, I heard the ferry was purchased from the French a few years ago, so bring along a European power adapter. I did find one, US style plug in the private bathroom on the side of the medicine cabinet at the top by the light. Hope that helps somebody!

247828366.name: Interesting experience
247828366.author: a TripAdvisor user
